fr:title.text: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
The coproduct monad container 1 + E \triangleleft T distributes over any monad container S \triangleleft P in exactly one way.
788#259unstable-259.xmlProof20241210Chris Purdy We have given the first 4 equations for a monad container distributive law and the isomorphisms T\ (\text {inl}\ *) \to S \cong S and T\ (\text {inr}\ e) \to S \cong 1 that: \begin {align*} &u\ (\text {inl}\ *)\ (\lambda \_ . s) = (s , \lambda \_ . \text {inl}\ *)\\ &u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f = u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ^S) = (\iota ^S , \lambda \_ . \text {inr}\ e)\\ &v\ \{\text {inl}\ *\}\ \{\lambda \_ . s\}\ (p , *) = (* , p) \end {align*} These constraints entirely define u, and therefore v also. Since the other distributive law equalities hold, u and v specify the unique distributive law (1 + E \triangleleft T) \circ (S \triangleleft P) \Rightarrow (S \triangleleft P) \circ (1 + E \triangleleft T).

Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers. They are in bijection with compatible compositions of monad containers.
